resources.string: Baking Techniques

You have all the ingredients measured, your sleeves rolled up and ready to start baking those chewy caramel cookies.
Everything is prepared and just waiting for you to start following the recipe and mix it.
But here’s the catch – you need different techniques to get the desired result of chewy cookies, bread or cupcakes.
The way you work with batter determines how will it turn out.
So get ready to learn all the baking techniques you might come across in the recipes.
Stirring:
Mixing the ingredients by moving them around with a spoon until they combine.
Beating:

More vigorous than stirring – moving ingredients around by hand or electric mixer, until they are smooth.
In general, 100 energetic hand-beaten stokes equal one minute of beating with an electric mixer.
Whipping:

Similar to beating but adds more air into the ingredients (like cream or egg whites).
Mix the ingredients using a whisk or electric mixer with a whisk attachment.

A lot of recipes require egg whites whipped into stiff or soft peaks. Before you begin whipping, make sure the bowl and whisk are clean and dry – even a bit of oil, water or egg yolk can prevent the egg whites from being stiff.
If you want your bowl to be really clean, wipe it with a cloth dipped in vinegar and then rinse and dry it.
Avoid using plastic bowls if you can as fat and grease tend to stick to plastic, which can reduce the volume of the whipped whites.

If some of the yolk breaks and falls into the whites before whipping them, you can remove it with a piece of kitchen towel.
Beat the whites slowly until they are foamy and then increase the speed to add as much air as possible into the whites. Continue until they form smooth and shiny peaks.
If you overbeat the whites (they lose their shine and start looking dry, grainy), add one more egg white and beat for a short time.
Whisking:
Combining ingredients by whipping briefly using a hand wire whisk.
Creaming:
Combining sugar with butter, margarine or shortening by beating by hand or with an electric mixer until it turns light and fluffy.
Kneading:

Working the yeast bread dough with an electric mixer (using dough hook attachments) or by hand.
This pushing, folding and pressing movement develops gluten in the dough, which gives it a smooth, elastic texture and helps it rise.
Folding:

Combining a light mixture (like whipped cream) into a heavier mixture (such as cake batter).
To fold egg whites into cake batter, start with taking about a quarter of the whipped whites and stir it into the yolk mixture as it will lighten the batter.
Put the remaining whites on top and use a large rubber spatula to cut through and separate the mixture through the middle.
Make sure you go all the way down to the bottom of the mixing bowl when cutting through.
Pull the spatula toward you to the edge of the bowl, turning it in the process to put some batter on top of the whites.
Turn the bowl by a quarter and repeat this motion (dipping and scooping) about 10-15 times – depending on the amount of mixture and batter.
Repeat until the whites and batter are combined.
Make sure to not overblend, or the whipped whites will lose their volume.
Boiling, Poaching and Steaming
Boiling:

Boiling means bringing water in a saucepan or a kettle to 100 degrees Celsius.
Covering the pot speeds up the boiling process and you will know that the water has come to a rapid boil when the bubbles are quickly breaking the water surface.
Boiling is not the best way to cook vegetables because the water leaches a lot of vitamins from them and makes it very easy to overcook them.
Parboiling and blanching

Parboiling means to briefly cook tough or salty foods in boiling water to soften their textures or skin and sometimes remove harsh flavours.
For example, the rice found in supermarkets is sometimes parboiled to shorten its cooking time but retain the nutrients.

Blanching is used when vegetables need to be cooked very briefly as they are plunged into boiling water for a minute.
The vegetables then must be immediately submerged in cold water to stop the cooking process and retain their colour.
Blanching can also be used to loosen skins and increase the flavour of certain ingredients (such as almonds, peaches and tomatoes).
Simmering and poaching

Simmering involves bringing the liquid to a gentle pre-boil, where few small air bubbles break through the surface (between 85 and 96 degrees Celsius).
This method is used for long, slow cooking and braising to add more flavour to the foods and make them tender.
Reducing

This is the process of thickening and intensifying the flavours of liquids, such as sauces, soups or juices.
However, it is very important not to over-reduce or burn the liquid.
Steaming

Steaming is very gentle.
It is the best way to cook vegetables because it allows them to retain more of the essential vitamins and minerals as well as the colour, flavour, shape and texture.
Using a stackable steamer is a great option if you would like to cook lots of different foods at the same time.
You can also very easily make your own steamer pan by simply placing a metal sieve or colander on top of a saucepan.

Steaming foods in a pan of water in the oven is called a water bath.
Cheesecakes and custards are often baked this way to prevent cracks.
Poaching

Poaching is the method of cooking foods (such as eggs or fish) in liquid which shows only slight movement, but no bubbles (between 70 and 82 degrees Celsius).
The flavour of the poaching liquid has a big effect on the final flavour of the finished dish, so it strongly advised to use stock or broth.
Buying and Storing Fruits and Vegetables

Fruits and vegetables are an important part of your diet and the quality of the produce directly impacts the quality of the meals you prepare.
Avoid buying produce with brown spots, wrinkled skin or not healthy-looking.
Make sure it is not overripe by squeezing.
Here are more tips about buying and storing produce:
Apples:
Should be crisp and firm. Keep refrigerated or store in a cool dry place. Can be kept for several weeks.
Artichokes and Asparagus:
Keep refrigerated and use within 2-3 days of purchase.
Avocados:

Should slightly yield to pressure when ripe. Keep at room temperature until fully ripened.
If not using right away, keep refrigerated to make them last for a few more days.
Bananas:

Eat before they turn completely brown.
Keep refrigerated to slow down ripening.
Bell peppers:
Keep refrigerated and use within 2 weeks of purchase.
Broccoli and cauliflower:
Keep refrigerated and use within a week of purchase.
Cabbage:
Keep refrigerated for 1-2 weeks.
Carrots:
Should be firm, but rubbery, without small roots growing all over them. Can be kept for several weeks when refrigerated.
Celery:
Should be firm and crisp. Keep refrigerated for 1-2 weeks.
Cherries and berries:
Keep refrigerated. Best consumed on the day of purchase as they get soft and moldy quickly.
Citrus fruits:
Keep refrigerated for up to 3 weeks.
Corn:
Keep refrigerated and use on the day of purchase.
Cucumbers and eggplant:
The skin should be firm, shiny, and smooth, without soft brown spots. Keep refrigerated for up to a week.
Garlic:
Should be firm and without green sprouts. Can be kept at room temperature or kept refrigerated to make it last longer.
Grapes:
Should look full and juicy with a powdery bloom on the skin. Keep refrigerated for up to a week.
Green beans:
Keep refrigerated and use within 3-4 days of purchase.
Leafy greens (beet tops, collards, kale, mustard greens):
Keep refrigerated and use within 1-2 days of purchase.
Mushrooms:
Mushrooms: Keep in the fridge in a paper bag and use within a week.
Onions, potatoes, shallots, and hard-shelled winter squash:
Onions, potatoes, and shallots should be firm. Store at a room temperature in a cool, dry and dark place
Pineapple:
Keep at room temperature away from heat and sun. Can also be refrigerated whole or cut up. Best consumed within a few days of purchase.
Salad greens:
Rinse, trim, and dry thoroughly before storing in plastic bags or wrapped in kitchen towel. Keep refrigerated and use within 3-4 days.
Spinach:
Rinse, trim, and dry thoroughly. Keep refrigerated and use within 2-3 days.
Summer squash (zucchini and yellow squash):
Keep refrigerated for up to a week.
Tomatoes:

Store at room temperature for more flavor.
Keep in a cool, dry place until fully ripened.
Consume when ripe or keep in a fridge for a few more days.
Let them return to room temperature before eating.
Tropical fruits:

Should be firm but yield slightly to pressure and should smell fruity.
Keep at room temperature until they are ripe, keep refrigerated afterwards.
Let them return to room temperature before eating.
Unripe melons and tree fruits (like pears, peaches, and nectarines):
Keep at room temperature until they are ripe. Keep refrigerated for a few more days.
Buying and Storing Meat, Poultry and Fish

Meat, poultry and fish are highly perishable products and need to be stored in the coldest part of the freezer.
Always keep them tightly wrapped, ideally in a separate drawer, to prevent their juices from coming into contact with other food.
Remember to always check expiration dates and never let meat, poultry, or fish thaw at room temperature.
It gives bacteria time to develop and might have unpleasant consequences.
Always defrost them in the fridge, which takes a lot more time (put it in the fridge the evening before you want to cook) but it is the safest method.
Beef

The quality of beef depends on the age of the animal, the amount of fat – marbling - in the cut (more is better), its colour and texture.
More tender cuts are usually cooked by roasting, broiling, grilling or sautéing.
The led tender cuts (ones that have more muscle tissue and not as much fat) are cooked by stewing and braising.

When buying meat, search for cuts that are bright red - make sure they are not grey or dull.
If you spot a lot of juice in the packaging, the meat might have been previously frozen and then thawed – look for fresh meat.
Boneless and well-trimmed cuts are more expensive but have more edible meat than untrimmed ones, which usually evens the price.

If you buy raw meat, use it within 2 days of purchase, before the expiration date or freeze it.
To do so, wrap it in aluminium foil, thick plastic wrap, or freezer bags and press out as much air as possible.
Don’t forget to date the packages. Keep minced beef frozen for up to 3 months and other cuts for up to 6 months.
Defrost in the fridge or microwave.
Chicken

When buying chicken, make sure it’s clean, free of visible blood stains (unless small and unobtrusive), not bruised and looks healthy.
Keep in mind that a chicken’s skin has a range of colours depending on its diet.
Remember to rinse under cold water and dry the meat before cooking.
Also cut away excess fat. After preparing poultry make sure to wash your hands, utensils and surfaces you used to make sure other food doesn’t get contaminated with bacteria.

Use the poultry within 1-2 days of purchase. You can freeze a whole, raw and wrapped chicken for up to 12 months.
Already cut parts can be frozen for up to 9 months.
Defrost chicken in the fridge, never at room temperature and make sure to keep it on top of something (like a plate) to prevent the juices from dripping on other food.
Cut up parts take about 3-6 hours to defrost in the fridge so make sure you take them out earlier.
If you need the meat fast, you can defrost in the microwave but do so on a lowest setting and make sure you use it immediately after thawing.
Minimising the risk of salmonella

There’s a high chance you’ve heard about a salmonella outbreak in a restaurant, school, or somewhere else.
This is a real hazard as majority of raw poultry (other meats to a much lesser extent) carries the bacteria.
It’s not easy to eliminate it from the meat as it may come from the soil on which the animal grew up, the food it ate, droppings or during the processing of meat.

Salmonella is rarely fatal but it can be a not very nice surprise during a picnic or family meal.
The bacteria can be killed by heating the food to 75 °C for 10 minutes (longer on lower temperatures).
You can reduce the risk of contamination by – surprisingly – not rinsing raw chicken in the sink as it risks contaminating the sink, pans/utensils in it, faucet, floor, and clothes.
There are some other ways you can minimise the chances of getting sick from the bacteria:

1. When buying poultry, make sure it’s securely packaged (no leaks).
You can ask the seller to wrap it in a plastic bag or do it yourself at checkout.
2. Put the meat in the fridge immediately when you get back home and cook within 2 days.
3. Never defrost chicken at room temperature. Defrost it in the fridge (chicken breast will take less than a day to thaw) or microwave (make sure you cook it immediately after thawing in this case).
4. Don’t touch raw poultry with dish towels that may come in contact with other surfaces.
5. Remember that freezing doesn’t kill bacteria.
6. Wash the cutting boards and knives thoroughly after handling raw chicken. Check your clothing for drips.
7. After handling raw meat, make sure to wash your hands thoroughly with soap (anti-bacterial soap is a good choice).
Taking into account how the chicken was raised

The easiest way for producers to mass raise chickens is in cages.
Their movement is very limited and they never see the outside world.
The chicken you buy might have also been raised in a big barn – they have bedding and more space to move.
Free-range chickens live in a barn and have continuous access to outdoors.
Organic chickens have a grown pasture access and are fed organic food.

The price of the meat and eggs depends on how the chicken was raised.
As you can guess, organic is the most expensive, while cage-grown chickens are the cheapest.
Fish and other seafood

There two categories of fish: lean and oily.
Some of the lean fish are: cod, haddock, halibut, sole, flounder, and snapper.
Oily fish have more intense flavour, more fatty acids that are good for your heart, and usually darker flesh.
Some of them are: salmon, tuna, swordfish, mackerel, and bluefish.
When purchasing oily fish but fillets with the skin on – this makes the fish hold together during cooking.
Lean fish are generally packaged without skin.

If you buy fish from the fisher/at the market, ask the seller what is the freshest.
Here are some other types of tasty fish to add variety to the usual salmon-or-tuna dilemma:
Bluefish: White, meaty flesh. Has a mild flavour and tastes best when pan-fried or braised.
Bluefish: White, meaty flesh. Has a mild flavour and tastes best when pan-fried or braised.
Cod: White, firm flesh. Has a mild flavour and can be baked, fried, broiled, or braised.
Haddock: White, meaty flesh. Has a mild flavour and tastes best pan-fried or braised.
Hake: Very similar to the cod. Mild flavoured but low in fat – make sure you don’t overcook it. Can be cooked same way as cod.
Porgy: White, firm flesh and low in fat. Has a very delicate flavour. Best grilled or broiled.
Tilapia: Has a mild flavour. The flesh holds together and can be cooked in various way.
Whiting (silver hake): White, semi firm and fine flesh. Subtle when pan-fried or broiled.

When buying fish, freshness is the most important.
A fresh fish has bright and clear eyes (not cloudy), the gills are deep red, not brownish.
The skin should be bright, clear with no trace of slime.
It may be counterintuitive, but a very fresh fish shouldn’t smell fishy. It might smell briny, not fishy.

If you’re buying fish fresh, ask the seller to cut fillets from the fish in front of you.
Pre-cut fillets should be lying on a bed of ice instead of wrapped in plastic (this can trap odour and bacteria).
They should look moist and lie flat (not curl at the edges).

Cook fresh fish and other seafood as soon as possible – best on the day of purchase.
You can freeze fresh and cleaned fish for 2-3 months. Wrap then in two layers of freezer wrap.
Refreezing compromises the texture of many types fish and other seafood so avoid it if you can.
Buying shellfish

Look for shellfish that are odourless and firmly closed.
Only buy closed mussels or clams. Fresh mussels, oysters, and clams should be eaten as soon as possible.
Store them for no more than 24hours – keep them in the fridge in a plastic bag with small holes to allow some air flow.
Shrimps are best bought in the shell and eaten on the day of purchase.
Be careful to not overcook shellfish because they become rubbery.

Confused by terms like jumbo and extra large when buying shrimp?
They aren’t very helpful so look the count number on the label or seafood display.
This number indicates how shrimp comprise 1 pound – the lower the count the bigger the shrimp.
A standard size is about 21-25 cont.
Choose the size of the shrimp based on what the recipe recommends.
Follow the same method when buying scallops. Labelling scallops as 20/30 means about 20-30 comprise 1 pound.
Considering where the seafood came from

About half of the seafood consumed today is farm-raised. Many types of fish and shellfish are endangered.
Therefore, aquaculture allows us to meet the demand for seafood without putting wild fish in more danger of extinction.
Farm-raised seafood is not bad for you or inferior.
Aquaculture is the breeding, rearing and harvesting plants and other aquatic animals in different types of water environments (like ponds, lakes, rivers, or even the ocean).

You can also find wild-caught and sustainably caught seafood.
Wild-caught fish are caught in their natural habitats.
Supporters of wild-caught fish claim that farmed fish have less healthy omega-3 fatty acids because of crowded conditions, are fed antibiotics, or dyed to look better.
However, catching wild fish puts them at risk of overfishing and becoming endangered or even extinct. Sustainably caught fish are fished keeping in mind the importance of sustaining wild populations and not putting other species at risk.
While farm-raised fish may have a different taste if you compare it with a wild-caught side by side, it’s mostly a matter of your personal taste.
Flour Types

There are many different kinds of flour, which have various level of protein.
For example, they can be made from either high-protein hard wheat, low-protein soft wheat or a combination.
Each kind of flour also has a different gluten content, which is a protein that becomes stretchy with beating or kneading, helping baked goods rise.
Plain (white) flour

This is the most commonly used type of flour.
It contains about 70% of the wheat grain.
Most of the bran and wheat germ is removed when the grains are milled.
All that is left is the white starchy part of the grain.
Plain flour is commonly used for cakes, pastries and biscuits. It is often combined with a rising agent (such as baking powder or bicarbonate of soda) when used to bake cakes.
Moreover, this type of flour is usually artificially whitened but it is possible to buy an unbleached variety if necessary.
Strong (bread) flour

Strong flour is made from ‘hard’ wheat varieties because all the bran and wheat germ is removed from the wheat grain when processed.
This makes it ideal for making bread because it is very high in gluten, which ensures that the dough will expand and rise well in order to produce a light loaf.
Strong flour is not suitable for cake recipes.
Self-rising flour

This is simply plain flour mixed with rising agents (such as baking powder or bicarbonate of soda).
The raising agent reacts during cooking and makes the dough expand to give a light and airy texture.
This type of flour can be easily made at home; however, because the raising agents are blended with plain flour during manufacturing, bought self-raising flour is more convenient to use.
Wholemeal flour

Wholemeal flour contains 100% of the wheat grain, including the bran and germ.
It does have a much higher fibre content than plain flour; however, wholemeal flour produces heavier results than white flour so is often used in combination.
Strong and self-rising varieties of wholemeal flour can also be found in shops.
Gluten-free flour
This is just like plain flour but without any gluten. Gluten-free flour is usually made from a blend of rice flour, potato flour, buckwheat and maize flour.
Additional tips:
Store flour in an airtight container in a cool, dry place.
Glossary of Greens

Greens range in taste from mild to pungent and even bitter.
The more variety of greens in the bowl, the better because there is more flavor and a higher nutritional content.
Most Popular Greens
Round lettuce
Often called “the traditional British lettuce”, it has soft green outer leaves and a slightly crispier, paler heart.
Iceberg lettuce

A pale green, round, densely packed lettuce which has crisp leaves.
Its refreshing flavour makes is perfect for sandwiches or to add a crunch to mixed salads.
Romaine (COS) lettuce

It has a long, oval head of tightly packed crisp leaves, which are rich in potassium and have a subtle nutty flavour.
They are traditionally used as base for Caesar salads with garlic, croutons, eggs and Parmesan cheese.
Little gem lettuce

A very small variety of Romaine lettuce with crispy, round leaves which have a sweet flavour.
This type of lettuce is usually used in Waldorf salad with celery, apple, walnuts and mayonnaise.
Baby leaf spinach

One of the most popular salad leaves, which are tender and sweet. It is best to eat raw baby spinach as it minimises the loss of nutrients.
It combines well with olive oil dressings but baby spinach also works well with warm salads, lentil dishes, grilled cheese or meat, eggs, and tomatoes.
Lamb’s lettuce

Its small spoon-shaped leaves have a nutty flavour.
This type of lettuce is often used in mixed salads with a mustard dressing, and goes especially well with potatoes and beetroots.
Rocket

These thin spiky leaves have a strong peppery flavour which are very versatile.
Some of the most common uses include cold salads, wilted in pasta or on top of a pizza.
Mizuna

This type of lettuce is very similar to rocket (light green serrated leaves with a soft texture).
It has a hot, mustardy flavour which works well in salads and stir-fries.
Radicchio

It has very distinctive, red leaves which have a slightly bitter flavour and a chewy texture similar to cabbage leaves.
Its most common uses include salads and as a garnish for savoury dishes.
Watercress

The leaves have a very distinct raw flavour, which is both peppery and slightly pungent.
Watercress is usually eaten in soup and salads.
Kale

A member of the cabbage family, which comes in two forms: one with smooth leaves and curly kale, which has crinkly leaves.
Both varieties have quite large leaves that have a strong and bitter flavour.
The tough centre stalk should be removed before using.
Kale is very commonly boiled and added to salads.
Herbs, Spices and Seasonings

Herbs and spices are essential flavouring ingredients.
Most herbs are produced from the leaves and stems of a variety of plants.
Spices, however, can come from plants’ roots, seeds, bark, buds or berries.

It is best to keep these essential dry herbs on hand: basil, bay leaves, dill, marjoram, oregano, parsley, rosemary, sage, tarragon and thyme.
Dried herbs have a more intense, concentrated flavour than fresh herbs.
Crush dried herbs between your fingers before adding them to a dish to get the most intense flavour.

Fresh herbs have a brighter, lighter and fresher taste than dried ones; however, they are best purchased fresh, refrigerated and used within a few days.
As a rule, if a recipe calls for one tablespoon of dried herbs you should use two tablespoons when using fresh.
Basil
Widely used in Italian and French cuisine; excellent with tomatoes, eggs, fish, pasta and poultry. Should be stored in cool, dark, dry places.
Bay leaves

They are pungent and have a sharp, bitter taste.
Add the dried leaves to long-cooking dishes such as soups, stews, marinades and roasts but remove them before serving the dish.
Chives
Chives have a mild, onion-like flavour which tastes great in cream sauces or soups; with chicken, eggs, shellfish and salads; or simply sprinkled as a garnish.
Cilantro

Dried version of cilantro is a lot paler in comparison to the fresh variety.
It works well with Mexican and Asian dishes, especially on rice, with fish and pork or in salsa, guacamole and bean dips.
Dill

Seeds are often used in pickling recipes.
Fresh leaves, however, are widely used in fish, shellfish and chicken dishes as well as omelettes and in salad dressings.
Marjoram
It has a very floral and woodsy flavour, which means that it can be added to almost any vegetable dish.
Mint

The two most common varieties are standard peppermint and spearmint.
Tastes excellent when paired with fresh fruit, lamb, peas or in chocolate desserts.
Oregano
It is an essential ingredient in Italian and Greek cooking as it’s widely used with tomato, egg or cheese based dishes; however, it also goes well with red meat, poultry, fish and vegetable stews.
Parsley
It is often used as a garnish because of its light and grassy flavour, which is why it’s best to use fresh parsley.
Rosemary
Its strong flavour makes it excellent with grilled meat (especially lamb) and in herb bread, or to flavour oils and marinade.
Sage

It has a very fragrant aroma with pine-like flavour.
Works well with fish and chicken, and in herb butter.
Tarragon

It has a strong anise flavour, which is widely used on chicken, pork, lamb, veal, fish and shellfish; however, it can also be used as flavouring for vinegar and in pickles, relishes, mustards and sauces.
Thyme

Thyme is great as an all-purpose seasoning because it has a subtle, dry aroma.
Try it with vegetables, meat, poultry, fish, soups, stews, and cream sauces.

Spices are almost always sold dried and they should be stored in a cool, dry place.
Many whole spices (such as peppercorns, nutmeg, cinnamon sticks and cumin seeds) are a lot more aromatic and flavourful than the pre-ground form.
Whole spices can also be added to soup, stew, braises and marinades to add extra flavour, and then removed before serving.
Allspice

The name “Allspice” comes from the fact that its flavour resembles a combination of cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves.
It is commonly used for savoury dishes such as Jerked meats, marinades, soups and stews.
It also works great in sweet dishes such as cakes, cookies, fruit pies and puddings.
Caraway Seeds
These are very common in German cuisine as they are essential for rye bread as well as sauerkraut, sausage, cheese, cabbage and soups.
Cardamom

Being one of the main ingredients in garam masala, it is traditionally used in Indian cooking.
Because of its intense, sweet flavour, it is also excellent in baked goods and pumpkin pie.
Cayenne or Red Pepper

A hot, powdered mixture made from dried and ground chili peppers.
It is often used in sauces, soups and marinades to add some extra spice.
Chili powder

A spicy blend of ground chilies, cumin, oregano and garlic powder.
Best used to flavour meat, sauces, stews and chili con carne.
Cinnamon

This is a sweet and aromatic spice from the bark of a tropical tree that can be used in both sweet and savoury dishes.
However, it is most commonly used as a baking spice.
Clove

Adds a strong, pungent and sweet flavour to sweet or savoury dishes.
Most common uses include applesauce, cookies and gingerbread.
Coriander Seeds

This spice has a very mild taste similar to a blend of lemon and sage.
It is very often used for pickling, curries, sausage and baked goods.
Cumin
A smoky and earthy spice that is essential to Middle Eastern, Indian and South-western U.S. cuisine.
Curry Powder

A blend of many spices that is widely used in Indian savoury dishes.
It can include more than a dozen different herbs and spices.
Use it to season meat, rice, sautéed vegetables, and to add flavour to curries.
Ginger
Essential in gingerbread – ground ginger is made from dehydrated fresh ginger. It has a sweet and spicy aroma.
Nutmeg

Nutmeg’s pungent and sweet flavour is delicious in white sauces, sweet sauces but also over eggnog, in puddings, fruit pies and spice cakes.
Best to use it freshly grated.
Paprika

The varieties range from sweet to hot or smoked.
However, all of them add a sweet flavour and red colour to dishes such as dips, creamy salads, dressings, stews, sautéed meats and fish.
Peppercorns

Black pepper is probably the world’s most popular spice because it is a universal condiment that can be used to flavour nearly every savoury dish.
White pepper, however, can be used to enrich cream sauces and white dishes for a pure white colour.
There are also other coloured peppercorns that can add a variety of flavour.
Saffrom

This is the world’s most expensive spice because it’s made from dried stigmas that need to be handpicked from a special variety of purple crocus flowers.
It can be bought as a powder or whole threads, and a little pinch goes a long way so it should be used sparingly.
It is essential to classic Mediterranean dishes like bouillabaisse and paella.
Turmeric

Turmeric is a yellow-orange powder that is intensely aromatic and has a bitter, pungent flavour.
It is a necessary ingredient of curry powder, but it also gives the American-style mustard its colour.

Using Knives Safely

Using knives can be accident-prone if you are not careful.
Don’t rush or let your mind wander somewhere else – you want to keep your fingers intact.
To help you avoid bloodshed, here are some safety rules to keep in mind when using knives:
Always use a cutting boards and don’t let it slide on the surface.

Using a cutting board with rubber feet will make it grip the surface better.
You can also place something under it (like a kitchen towel) to prevent it from moving.
Keep your fingers clear of the blade.

While this may seem obvious, as students we don’t want to waste our food.
So that quite thick slice of something you want to put on your sandwich is too thick.
What do you do? Try and slice it.
This puts your fingers dangerously close and it’s easy to slip by accident.
Reconsider taking risks – is an extra tomato slice worth it?
Always slice away from your hand.

Unless there is no way around it (like when you are peeling an apple), never turn the blade toward your hand.
Try to keep it turned the other way when slicing, chipping or mincing.
Keep your fingers curled under when slicing.

You shouldn’t move the knife away or towards food - instead, move the food towards it.
If you keep your fingers curled and happen to misjudge the distance, you’ll likely hit a hard knuckle instead of your fingertip.
Working with Eggs

Eggs are widely used in recipes, especially baking.
Unfortunately, we are only interested in what is inside the shell. Therefore, in order to get the good stuff out, you need a way to break the shell.
Some recipes require separating the yolk from egg white as well – don’t worry, we’ve got you covered in both cases.
Breaking the egg:

1. Have a glass or a small bowl ready.
Always break the eggs into a separate container before adding them to a recipe – if a shell piece falls in, you can take it out before it ends up in the pancakes.
2. Hold the egg in one hand.

3. Tap the egg gently on the side of the glass/bowl to break the shell.
Be careful to not tap too hard or the egg will be full of shell pieces.

4. Put two thumbs inside the crack and carefully open the egg.
The yolk and white should fall into the container.
Separating the egg:

You will see quite a few recipes that require separated yolks and egg whites. But don’t worry, it’s not as hard as it may seem.
Just follow the instructions on how to separate an egg while leaving the yolk intact:
1. Prepare two small bowls or cups.
2. Hold the egg in one hand and tap it gently on the side of one of the bowls – just enough to crack the shell and break the membrane without damaging the yolk or shattering the shell.
3. Put two thumbs inside the crack and gentry pry the shell open.
4. Let most of the egg white fall into one of the bowls.
5. Carefully pass the yolk back and forth from one part of the shell to the other and release more white into the bowl each time.

6. When all the white is in the bowl/cup, put the yolk into the other one – don’t worry if it break at this point.
